thread.title: The rise of the JoJo bow - the latest trend to hit primary schools
thread.title_full: The rise of the JoJo bow - the latest trend to hit primary schools

author: Emma Gill
title: The rise of the JoJo bow - the latest trend to hit primary schools
text:
JoJo bows have become the latest trend among young girls Share Get   
If you have a daughter at dance class or primary school you've probably noticed their group of friends have become a whole lot louder recently - and we don't mean their voices. 
That's because huge, brightly-coloured JoJo bows have become the latest trend among young girls. 
Usually worn to decorate a high ponytail, they have become a must-have fashion accessory thanks to JoJo Siwa, a 13-year-old YouTube star and dancer in the US reality show Dance Moms. Claire's Accessories has its own range of JoJo bows Read More Work starts on thrilling tree-top adventure playground at Heaton Park - including mid-air trampolines 
The bows are available in high street branches of Claire's Accessories , which has its own collaboration with JoJo and typically cost between £8 and £10 . It sells them online too but most of the products are currently out of stock. 
Unsurprisingly the big bows have not gone unnoticed in schools and with one reportedly banning the bows because 'they're not part of school uniform', parents in Manchester are wondering whether local schools will follow suit. JoJo bow from Claire's Accessories Read More When is World Book Day 2017? 
Anna Gray, from Stockport, knows all about the demand for the bows. 
She set up her own business Tutu Bowtique selling bows and tutus at the beginning of this year and keeps getting requests for the JoJo style. 
She said: "The demand for them has exploded around here, we live in the Stockport area and I don't think there is a single girl in my children's school that doesn't wear one. 
"It would be a shame if schools say they can't be worn as it is one tiny bit of personal expression while wearing a school uniform and they aren't hurting anyone so I say let them enjoy putting these bows in their hair." One of Anna's JoJo bows from Tutu Bowtique Read More Dessert restaurant Fireworks, Ice Cream and Desserts to open in Altrincham 
Similar bows have of course been around for years - often worn by competitive dancers, gymnasts and cheerleaders. 
But JoJo's huge online presence - she has 4.5 million followers on Instagram and nearly three million on YouTube - is driving the current popularity. 
You can also get hold of JoJo style bows on Amazon and eBay . Read More
